thread.title: VW class action 'most likely'
thread.title_full: VW class action 'most likely' | Business Spectator

author: Michael Roddan
title: VW class action 'most likely'
text:
Compensation law firm Maurice Blackburn says Volkswagen's recall of around 90,000 Australian vehicles means "a consumer class action is almost certainly now the only avenue for redress".
Maurice Blackburn said the car manufacturer's recall does not address the compensation concerns of affected car owners, after it announced that Australian cars had been fitted with emissions test-cheating software.
"Today’s announcement from VW had failed to provide any clarity on how it is intending to compensate consumers who might lose thousands of dollars in increased running costs or reduced re-sale value for affected vehicles," Maurice Blackburn class actions principle Damian Scattini said.
The scandal has rocked Europe's largest auto manufacturer, which last month issued a profit warning and said it would take a €6.5 billion ($US7.33 billion) charge to earnings to pay for repairing up to 11 million vehicles affected by the emissions scam. The events have also claimed the scalp of its chief executive, who has resigned in the wake of the revelations.
Maurice Blackburn said almost 700 people around Australia had already registered their interest in a potential class action, and expects the number to grow.
“Today’s announcement reveals that the scope of people affected in Australia is much larger than was first thought, and in our view a class action is now most likely,” Mr Scattini said.
The Australian consumer watchdog, the ACCC, has said an enforcement investigation into Volkswagen is a priority for the regulator, which will not hesitate to take action if consumers were exposed to misleading representations.
The use of defeat devices is prohibited under design rules covered by Australian consumer law mandatory safety standards. The maximum penalty for each breach of the law is $1.1 million, which could end in a total fine into the billions of dollars for Volkwagen.
“It beggars belief that VW got itself into this situation in the first place but it adds insult to injury for the company not to address the issue of compensation to vehicle owners," Mr Scattini said.
“The class actions mechanism is the best chance people have of holding companies that have caused mass wrongdoing to account."
